conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; size and position depend on light source position relative to object and surface.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
Moving the light source backward increases the angle between light rays and the surface.
Shadows will shift forward and move closer to the objects as the light source moves backward.
The size of the shadows will decrease due to the angle of light rays becoming more perpendicular to the surface.
Shadow A (Circular Object) moves closer to the object and decreases in size.
Shadow B (Rectangular Object) moves closer to the object and decreases in size.
Shadow C (Cylindrical Object) moves closer to the object and decreases in size.
Shadow D (Paper Airplane) moves closer to the object and decreases in size.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and decrease in size.
